abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Center West
            Agricultural Development Project for the Ivory Coast was
            satisfactory. The project achieved many of its objectives,
            institutional development was partially successful,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, approaches to extension
            and land management now give full credit to pilot projects
            that start with selected zones and gradually involve more
            farmers and village groups in managing resources. Second,
            the objectives and scope of integrated rural development
            projects should be kept at an optimally manageable level.
            Finally, it is important to have a participative approach to
            land tenure administration.
